column1: West Java (Indonesian: Jawa Barat; Sundanese: ᮏᮝ ᮊᮥᮜᮧᮔ᮪) is a province of Indonesia on the western part of the island of Java
column2: with its provincial capital in Bandung. West Java is bordered by the province of Banten and the country's capital region of Jakarta to the west
column3: the Java Sea to the north
column4: the province of Central Java to the east and the Indian Ocean to the south. The province is the homeland of the Sundanese people
column5: the second-largest ethnic group in Indonesia after the Javanese.

column1: West Java was one of the early eight provinces of Indonesia formed following the country's independence proclamation and was later legally re-established on 14 July 1950. In 1966
column2: the city of Jakarta was split off from West Java as a 'special capital region' (Daerah Khusus Ibukota)
column3: with a status equivalent to that of a province
column4: while in 2000 the western parts of the province were in turn split away to form a separate Banten province.

column2: West Java is the most populous province of Indonesia with a population of 49
column4: 858 as of mid 2020. The province's largest cities
column5: Bekasi and Bandung
column6: are the third and fourth most populous cities proper in Indonesia
column7: respectively. As a satellite city within the Jakarta metropolitan area
column8: Bekasi experiences a highly rapid population growth
column9: having surpassed the West Java capital of Bandung in 2012. Nonetheless
column10: Bandung remains one of the most densely populated cities proper in the world
column13: are respectively the seventh and tenth most populous suburbs in the world.

column1: The oldest human inhabitant archaeological findings in the region were unearthed in Anyer (the western coast of Java) with evidence of bronze and iron metallurgical culture dating to the first millennium AD. The prehistoric Buni culture (near present-day Bekasi) clay pottery were later developed with evidence found in Anyer to Cirebon. Artefacts (dated from 400 BC — AD 100)
column2: such as food and drink containers
column3: were found mostly as burial gifts. There is also archaeological evidence in Batujaya Archaeological Site dating from the 2nd century and
column4: according to Dr Tony Djubiantono
column5: the head of Bandung Archaeology Agency
column6: Jiwa Temple in Batujaya
column7: Karawang
column8: West Java was also built around this time.One of the earliest known recorded history in Indonesia is from the former Tarumanagara kingdom
column9: where seven fourth century stones are inscribed in Wengi letters (used in the Pallava period) and in Sanskrit describing the kings of the kingdom Tarumanagara. Records of Tarumanegara's administration lasted until the sixth century
column10: which coincides with the attack of Srivijaya
column11: as stated in the Kota Kapur inscription (AD 686).

column1: The Sunda Kingdom subsequently became the ruling power of the region
column2: as recorded on the Kebon Kopi II inscription (AD 932).An Ulama
column3: Sunan Gunung Jati
column4: settled in Cirebon
column5: with the intention of spreading the word of Islam in the pagan town. In the meantime
column6: the Sultanate of Demak in central Java grew to an immediate threat against the Sunda kingdom. To defend against the threat
column7: Prabu Surawisesa Jayaperkosa signed a treaty (known as the Luso-Sundanese Treaty) with the Portuguese in 1512. In return
column8: the Portuguese were granted an accession to build fortresses and warehouses in the area
column9: as well as form trading agreements with the kingdom. This first international treaty of West Java with the Europeans was commemorated by the placement of the Padrao stone monument at the bank of the Ciliwung River in 1522.

column1: Although the treaty with the Portuguese had been established
column2: it could not come to realization. Sunda Kalapa harbour fell under the alliance of the Sultanate of Demak and the Sultanate of Cirebon (former vassal state of Sunda kingdom) in 1524
column3: after their troops under Paletehan alias Fadillah Khan had conquered the city. In 1524/1525
column4: their troops under Sunan Gunung Jati also seized the port of Banten and established the Sultanate of Banten which was affiliating with the Sultanate of Demak. The war between the Sunda kingdom with Demak and Cirebon sultanates then continued for five years until a peace treaty was made in 1531 between King Surawisesa and Sunan Gunung Jati. From 1567 to 1579
column5: under the last king Raja Mulya
column6: alias Prabu Surya Kencana
column7: the Sunda kingdom declined
column8: essentially under the pressure from Sultanate of Banten. After 1576
column9: the kingdom could not maintain its capital at Pakuan Pajajaran (the present-day Bogor) and gradually the Sultanate of Banten took over the former Sunda kingdom's region. The Mataram Sultanate from central Java also seized the Priangan region
column10: the southeastern part of the kingdom.

column2: the Dutch and the British trading companies established their trading ships in West Java after the falldown of Sultanate of Banten. For the next three hundred years
column3: West Java fell under the Dutch East Indies' administration. West Java was officially declared as a province of Indonesia in 1950
column4: referring to a statement from Staatblad number 378. On 17 October 2000
column5: as part of nationwide political decentralisation
column6: Banten was separated from West Java and made into a new province. There have been recent proposals to rename the province Pasundan ("Land of the Sundanese") after the historical name for West Java.

column2: the Province of West Java has been subdivided into 9 cities (Indonesian: Kota) and 17 regencies (Indonesian: Kabupaten). These 26 cities and regencies are divided into 620 districts (Indonesian: Kecamatan)
column3: which comprise 1
column4: 576 urban villages (Indonesian: Kelurahan) and 4
column5: 301 rural villages (Indonesian: Desa). An 18th regency was formed in October 2012 – Pangandaran Regency – from the southern half of Ciamis Regency; and on 25 October 2013
column6: the Indonesian House of Representatives (DPR) began reviewing draft laws on the establishment of 57 prospective regencies (and 8 new provinces)
column7: including a further three regencies in West Java – South Garut (Garut Selatan)

column1: West Java borders Jakarta and Banten province to the west
column2: and Central Java to the east. To the north is the Java Sea. To the south is the Indian Ocean. Unlike most other provinces in Indonesia which have their capitals in coastal areas
column3: the provincial capital
column4: Bandung
column5: is located in the mountainous area in the centre of the province. Banten Province was formerly part of West Java Province but was created a separate province in 2000. West Java
column6: in the densely populated western third of Java
column7: is home to almost 1 out of every 5 Indonesians.

column2: as a part of the Pacific Ring of Fire
column3: have more mountains and volcanoes than any of the other provinces in Indonesia. The vast volcanic mountainous region of inland West Java is traditionally known as Parahyangan (also known as Priangan or Preanger) which means "The abode of hyangs (gods)". It is considered as the heartland of the Sundanese people. The highest point of West Java is the stratovolcano Mount Cereme (3
column4: 078 meters) bordering Kuningan and Majalengka Regencies. West Java has rich and fertile volcanic soil. Agriculture
column5: especially traditional dry rice cultivation (known as ladang or huma)
column6: has become the main way of life of traditional Sundanese people. Since the colonial VOC and Dutch East Indies era
column7: West Java has been known as a productive plantation area for coffee
column10: and many other cash crops. The mountainous region of West Java is also a major producer of vegetables and decorative flowering plants. The landscape of the province is one of volcanic mountains
column16: and natural sea harbours.Flowing through Bandung Basin to the northeast is Citarum River
column17: the longest and most important river in the province. This 300-km long river is the site of 3 dams
column20: and Jatiluhur Dam. The river is heavily polluted by industrial and household sewage to the point that it has been called as 'the world's dirtiest river' by some.

column2: the economy of the Sundanese people in West Java relied heavily on rice cultivation. Ancient kingdoms established in West Java such as the Tarumanagara and Sunda Kingdom are known to have relied on rice taxes and agriculture revenues. The cycle of life of the ancient Sundanese people revolved around the rice crop cycle. Traditional rice harvest festivals such as the Seren Taun were important. The ancient goddess of rice
column3: Nyai Pohaci Sanghyang Asri
column4: is revered in Sundanese culture. Traditionally
column5: Sundanese people often used dry rice cultivation (ladang). After the Mataram expanded to the Priangan area in the early 17th century following the Sultan Agung campaign against Dutch Batavia
column6: sawah (wet rice cultivation) began to be adopted in the northern lowlands of West Java. Regencies such as Indramayu
column7: Cirebon
column9: Karawang and Bekasi are now well known as key rice producing areas. The mountainous region of West Java supplies vegetables
column10: flower and many horticultural produce to Jakarta and Bandung. Animal farms in West Java produce dairy products and meats.

column1: During the Dutch East India Company (VOC) and Dutch East Indies era
column2: West Java fell under Dutch administration centered in Batavia. The Dutch colonial government introduced cash crops such as tea
column3: coffee
column4: and quinine. Since the 18th century
column5: West Java (known as "De Preanger") was known as a productive plantation area
column6: and became integrated with global trade and economy. Services such as transportation and banking were provided to cater for wealthy Dutch plantation owners. West Java is known as one of the earliest developed regions in the Indonesian archipelago. In the early 20th century
column7: the Dutch colonial government developed infrastructures for economic purposes
column8: especially to support Dutch plantations in the region. Roads and railways were constructed to connect inland plantations area with urban centers such as Bandung and port of Batavia.

column2: West Java became a supporting region for Jakarta
column3: the Indonesian capital. Jakarta remained as the business and political center of Indonesia. Several regencies and cities in West Java such as Bogor
column4: Bekasi and Depok were developed as supporting areas for Jakarta and came to form the Greater Jakarta area or Jabodetabek (JAkarta
column5: BOgor
column6: DEpok
column7: TAngerang and BEKasi). The northern area of West Java has become a major industrial area. Areas such as Bekasi
column8: Cikarang and Karawang are sprawling with factories and industries. The area in and around Bandung also developed as industrial area.

column1: Tourism is an important industry in West Java
column2: and the Bandung and Puncak areas have long been known as popular weekend destinations for Jakartans. Today Bandung has developed into a shopping destination
column3: popular not only among local Indonesian especially Jakartans
column4: but also with neighboring Malaysian and Singaporean visitors. The history-rich coastal city of Cirebon is also a cultural tourism destination since the city has several kratons and historical sites such as Gua Sunyaragi. Other tourist destinations include the Bogor Botanical Garden
column5: Safari Park of Indonesia
column6: Tangkuban Perahu crater
column7: Pelabuhanratu Bay
column9: Kawah Putih crater to the south of Bandung

column1: West Java is the native homeland of Sundanese people which forms the largest ethnic group in West Java

column3: including West Java

column5: the province has attracted various people from throughout Indonesia. Other Native Indonesian ethnic groups such as Minangkabau
column6: Batak
column7: Malay
column10: Ambonese and many other Indonesians who migrated to and settled in West Java cities can also be easily found. West Java urban areas also have a significant population of Chinese Indonesians.

column1: The Sundanese share Java island with the Javanese people and primarily live in West Java. Although the Sundanese live in the same island as the Javanese
column2: their culture is distinct and they likewise consider themselves to live in a separate cultural area called Pasundan or Tatar Sunda. Someone moving from West Java Province to Central or East Java Provinces is literally said to be moving from Sunda to Java worlds. Bandung
column3: the capital city of West Java
column4: is considered as the cultural heartland of Sundanese people. Many indigenous Sundanese artforms were developed in this city. The nearby province of Banten
column5: which was formerly part of West Java before it became its own province
column6: is similar in this regard and is also considered to be part of Pasundan as well.

column1: In addition to the Sundanese forms of Gamelan in Parahyangan
column2: the region of Cirebon retains its own distinct musical traditions. Amongst Cirebons' varying Gamelan ensembles the two most frequently heard are Gamelan Pelog (a non-equidistant heptatonic tuning system) and Gamelan Prawa (a semi-equidistant pentatonic tuning system). Gamelan Pelog is traditionally reserved for Tayuban
column3: Wayang Cepak
column4: and for listening and dance music of the Kratons in Cirebon. Whereas Gamelan Prawa is traditionally reserved for Wayang Purwa.

column1: Cirebon also retains specialized Gamelan ensembles including: Sekaten
column2: which is played in the Kratons to mark important times in the Islamic calendar. Denggung
column3: also a Kraton ensemble which is believed to have a number of "supernatural powers". And Renteng
column4: an ensemble found in both Cirebon and Parahyangan that is known for its loud and energetic playing style.

column1: Tembang Sunda is a genre of Sundanese vocal music accompanied by a core ensemble of two Kacapi (zither) and a  Suling (bamboo flute). Tembang means song or poem and Sunda is a geographical
column2: historical
column3: and cultural construct which signifies home for the Sundanese people of Indonesia. The music and poetry of tembang Sunda are closely associated with the Parahyangan (literally the abode of the gods)
column4: the highland plateau that transverses the central and southern parts of Sunda. The natural environment of Priangan
column5: an agricultural region surrounded by mountains and volcanoes
column6: is reflected in some songs of the tembang Sunda.Kacapi suling is tembang Sunda minus vocal.

column1: Tarawangsa is a genuine popular art is performed on ensemble consists of tarawangsa (a violin with an end pin) and the jentreng (a kind of seven-stringed zither). It is accompanied by a secret dance called Jentreng. The dance is a part of a ritual celebrating the goddess of paddy Dewi Sri. Its ceremonial significance is associated with a ritual of thanksgiving associated with the rice harvest. Tarawangsa can also be played for healing or even purely for entertainment.
The three main types of Sundanese bamboo ensembles are angklung
column2: calung
column3: karinding and arumba. The exact features of each ensemble vary according to context
column4: related instruments
column5: and relative popularity.

column1: Angklung is a generic term for sets of tuned
column2: shaken bamboo rattles. Angklung consists of a frame upon which hang several different lengths of hollow bamboo. Angklungs are played like handbells
column3: with each instrument played to a different note. Angklung rattles are played in interlocking patterns
column4: usually with only one or two instruments played per person. The ensemble is used in Sundanese processions
column5: sometimes with trance or acrobatics. Performed at life-cycle rituals and feasts (hajat)
column6: angklung is believed to maintain balance and harmony in the village. In its most modern incarnation
column7: angklung is performed in schools as an aid to learning about music.

column1: The Angklung got more international attention when Daeng Soetigna
column2: from Bandung
column3: West Java
column4: expanded the angklung notations not only to play traditional pélog or sléndro scales
column5: but also diatonic scale in 1938. Since then
column6: angklung is often played together with other western music instruments in an orchestra. One of the first well-known performances of angklung in an orchestra was during the Bandung Conference in 1955.

column2: the instruments of the calung ensemble are of bamboo
column3: but each consists of several differently tuned tubes fixed onto a piece of bamboo; the player holds the instrument in his left hand and strikes it with a beater held in his right. The highest-pitched calung has the greatest number of tubes and the densest musical activity; the lowest-pitched
column4: with two tubes
column5: has the least. Calung is nearly always associated with earthy humor
column6: and is played by men.

column1: Arumba refers to a set of diatonically tuned bamboo xylophones
column2: often played by women. It is frequently joined by modern instruments
column3: including a drum set
column4: electric guitar
column5: bass
column6: and keyboards.

column1: Wayang golek is a traditional form of puppetry from Sunda. Unlike the better-known leather shadow puppets (wayang kulit) found in the rest of Java and Bali
column2: wayang golek puppets are made from wood and are three-dimensional
column3: rather than two. They use a banana palm in which the puppets stand
column4: behind which one puppeteer (dalang) is accompanied by his gamelan orchestra with up to 20 musicians. The gamelan uses a five-note scale as opposed to the seven-note western scale. The musicians are guided by the drummer
column5: who in turn is guided by signals from the puppet master dalang gives to change the mood or pace required. Wayang golek are used by the Sundanese to tell the epic play "Mahabarata" and various other morality type plays.

column1: Sundanese dance shows the influence of the many groups that have traded and settled in the area over the centuries
column2: and includes variations from graceful to dynamic syncopated drumming patterns
column3: quick wrist flicks
column4: sensual hip movements
column5: and fast shoulder and torso isolations.

column1: Jaipongan is probably the most popular traditional social dance of Sundanese people. It can be performed in solo
column2: in group
column3: or in pair.

column1: The Tari Merak (Peafowl Dance) is a female dance inspired by the movements of a peafowl and its feathers blended with the classical movements of Sundanese dance.
